soln_description:
(1) $a_{n+1}=f\left(a_{n}\right)=\frac{a_{n}+3}{2 a_{n}-4}$, where $f(x)=\frac{x+3}{2 x-4}$. Solving the equation $f(x)=x$, i.e., $\frac{x+3}{2 x-4}=x, 2 x^{2}-5 x-3=0$, we find that $f(x)$ has two fixed points $x_{1}=-\frac{1}{2}, x_{2}=3$, thus
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a_{n+1}-\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)=\frac{a_{n}+3}{2 a_{n}-4}-\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)=\frac{2\left(a_{n}+\frac{1}{2}\right)}{2 a_{n}-4}, \\
a_{n+1}-3=\frac{a_{n}+3}{2 a_{n}-4}-3=\frac{-5\left(a_{n}-3\right)}{2 a_{n}-4} .
\end{array}
$$

Since $a_{n} \neq 3$ (otherwise, from (2) we can deduce $a_{1}=3 \neq \frac{1}{2}$, which is a contradiction), dividing (1) by (2) gives
$$
\frac{a_{n+1}+\frac{1}{2}}{a_{n+1}-3}=\left(-\frac{2}{5}\right)\left(\frac{a_{n}+\frac{1}{2}}{a_{n+1}-3}\right) \text {. }
$$

Let $y_{n}=\frac{a_{n}+\frac{1}{2}}{a_{n}-3}$, then $y_{n}$ is a geometric sequence with the first term $y_{1}=\frac{a_{1}+\frac{1}{2}}{a_{1}-3}=-\frac{2}{5}$ and common ratio $-\frac{2}{5}$, thus $y_{n}=-\frac{2}{5}\left(-\frac{2}{5}\right)^{n-1}$, i.e., $\frac{a_{n}+\frac{1}{2}}{a_{n}-3}=\left(-\frac{2}{5}\right)^{n}$,
solving for $a_{n}$ gives $a_{n}=\frac{-5^{n}+(-1)^{n-1} 3 \cdot 2^{n+1}}{2 \cdot 5^{n}+(-1)^{n-1} \cdot 2^{n+1}}$.
(2) $a_{n+1}=f\left(a_{n}\right)=\frac{a_{n}-4}{a_{n}-3}$, where $f(x)=\frac{x-4}{x-3}$, solving the equation $f(x)=x$, i.e., $\frac{x-4}{x-3}=x$, $x^{2}-4 x+4=0$ we find that $f(x)$ has only one fixed point $x_{0}=2$, thus
$$
a_{n+1}-2=\frac{a_{n}-4}{a_{n}-3}-2=\frac{-a_{n}+2}{a_{n}-3} .
$$

Since $a_{n} \neq 2$ (otherwise, from (3) we can deduce $a_{1}=2 \neq 5$ which is a contradiction), we have
$$
\frac{1}{a_{n+1}-2}=\frac{-a_{n}+3}{a_{n}-2}=-1+\frac{1}{a_{n}-2},
$$

hence $\frac{1}{a_{n}-2}$ is an arithmetic sequence with the first term $\frac{1}{a_{1}-2}=\frac{1}{3}$ and common difference $d=-1$, so
$$
\frac{1}{a_{n}-2}=\frac{1}{3}+(n-1)(-1)=\frac{4}{3}-n=\frac{4-3 n}{3},
$$

solving for $a_{n}$ gives $a_{n}=\frac{3}{4-3 n}+2=\frac{6 n-11}{3 n-4}$.
informal_statement:
Example 6 Find the general term of the following recursive sequences:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { (1) } a_{1}=\frac{1}{2}, a_{n+1}=\frac{a_{n}+3}{2 a_{n}-4}(n \geqslant 1) \text {; } \\
\text { (2) } a_{1}=5, a_{n+1}=\frac{a_{n}-4}{a_{n}-3}(n \geqslant 1) .
\end{array}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 6 Find the general term of the following recursive sequences:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { (1) } a_{1}=\frac{1}{2}, a_{n+1}=\frac{a_{n}+3}{2 a_{n}-4}(n \geqslant 1) \text {; } \\
\text { (2) } a_{1}=5, a_{n+1}=\frac{a_{n}-4}{a_{n}-3}(n \geqslant 1) .
\end{array}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_283587 {a : ℕ → ℝ} (ha : a 1 = 1 / 2) (h : ∀ n ≥ 1, a (n + 1) = (a n + 3) / (2 * a n - 4)) :
    ∀ n ≥ 1, a n = (-5 ^ n + (-1) ^ (n - 1) * 3 * 2 ^ (n + 1)) / (2 * 5 ^ n + (-1) ^ (n - 1) * 2 ^ (n + 1)) := by

soln_description:
11. Solution: Let $g(x)=a x-f(x)$,

then $g^{\prime}(x)=a-\frac{2 \cos x+1}{(2+\cos x)^{2}}=a-\frac{2}{2+\cos x}+ \frac{3}{(\cos x+2)^{2}}=3\left(\frac{1}{2+\cos x}-\frac{1}{3}\right)^{2}+a-\frac{1}{3}$,

thus when $a \geqslant \frac{1}{3}$, $g^{\prime}(x) \geqslant 0$, so $g(x)$ is an increasing function on $[0, \infty)$, and since $g(0)=0$, when $x \geqslant 0$, $g(x) \geqslant g(0)=0$, i.e., $f(x) \leqslant a x$.

When $0 < a < \frac{1}{3}$, let $h(x)=\sin x - 3ax$,

then $h^{\prime}(x)=\cos x - 3a > 0$, so $h(x)$ is an increasing function on $(0, \arccos 3a)$, hence when $x \in (0, \arccos 3a)$, $h(x) > h(0) = 0$, i.e., $\sin x > 3ax$.

Thus, when $x \in (0, \arccos 3a)$, $f(x)=\frac{\sin x}{2+\cos x} > \frac{\sin x}{3} > ax$.

When $a < 0$, $f(x) > 0 \geqslant a \cdot \frac{\pi}{2}$, therefore, the range of $a$ is $\left[\frac{1}{3},+\infty\right)$.
informal_statement:
11. (15 points) Let the function $f(x)=\frac{\sin x}{2+\cos x}$. If for any $x^{3} \geqslant 0$, we have $f(x) \leqslant a x$, find the range of the real number $a$.

保留源文本的换行和格式，直接输出翻译结果。
formal_statement:
import Mathlib
